comments.commentBody:
Richard, Ronald Reagan had a saying "trust but verify", but he was dealing with someone who gave reason to believe he could be trusted. Given trump's track record, there's every reason to believe he is untrustworthy, so it's only appropriate that "verify" should come before "trust".

I should not be surprised that you invoked the false equivalence of Vince Foster. Nice try, though. Kellyanne Conway will be proud of you.

Netanyahu is callously insulting and alienating the majority of Americans for his short term political gain - while his delusional supporters somehow imagine that Israel will be able to survive in the long run without the support of these very Americans. Perhaps everyone needs a reminder that it's not Trump who pays for Israel's defense, it's the American people. And the more Netanyahu throws tantrums when he doesn't get absolutely everything he wants from us the less likely we will be to oblige in the future. Not that he cares, but the people of Israel may one day pay horribly for his arrogance and disrespect towards the American people. As one who supports a secure and prosperous Israel, I hope I'm wrong.

I should be plain for all to see that the people of Israel (as expressed through their elected government) want the land, peace be damned. The settlements constitute slow annexation.

And the fact of the matter is that the settlements have been a great success, at taking land and making peace increasingly inconceivable.

That is Netanyahu's goal -- by making peace inconceivable there is no reason as the Israelis see it to halt the settlements. Take it all! Of course where those pesky arabs go, is not a question Netanyahu will give an answer to. One suspects he has one: a very ugly one.
Do what they will, at some point they will be so outnumbered that they will again suffer. Make a fair deal now and live in peace, or face another disaster.
I think Netanyahu's philosophy is "Do what I need to do to stay in power now, and let the future worry about the future. After all, I'll be dead."
And now they have the power trifecta: Trump, Putin, and Netanyahu. Three power-mad peas in a pod.

In doing the Times crossword puzzle this evening, I came to the entry at 38 Down. The fill required four letters, and I already had TI_S. Then I saw the clue: Some decorative containers.

When I was 10 or so, at summer camp, our counselor, a medical student, told us about a friend's answer to a test question. Asked to name three benefits of mother's milk, the friend could think of only two biologically relevant answers, supplying for the third benefit "it comes in beautiful containers."

Pass the madeleines.

and Elke

L.J.K.- I am PLOTZing !

I didn't notice that one, but I was briefly brought to a halt by the clue for 34a.

Maybe it's a colloquialism.

LJK, the same thing happened to me at 19A with the last letter of Francona's nickname, but I didn't have the 'beautiful containers' story.

And of course, you lucked out with the 38D...

Double reco for the madeleines.

The international community considers the settlements in occupied territory to be illegal, and the United Nations has repeatedly upheld the view that Israel's construction of settlements constitutes a violation of the Fourth Geneva Convention. Israeli neighborhoods in East Jerusalem and communities in the Golan Heights, the latter of which has been annexed by Israel, are also considered settlements by the international community, which does not recognise Israel's annexations of these territories. The International Court of Justice also says these settlements are illegal in a 2004 advisory opinion.

Israel will never give up military control of the Jordan River valley, nor the airspace above any Palestinian territory in the West Bank, because of their strategic importance. Imagine if Gaza had a functioning air force continually invading and bombing Israel.

Once these facts are recognized, then we have to look for alternatives to a Palestinian state in the West Bank. Because any self-government accommodations there won't ever really be a true country with full sovereignty.

Of course, the Palestinians could look to Jordan for such a state. Or perhaps the borders of Jordan, Syria, Egypt and Israel (and while we are at it, Iraq and Kurdistan) could be substantially redrawn with a Palestinian state in mind.

I'm sure many people already know this, but it bears repeating because some people don't understand what a realistic two-state solution really means.

So all this noise about the demise of the two-state solution is overblown: the same watered down Palestinian "state" (read: something less than the Vatican) remains achievable. But the idea of a Palestinian state with full sovereignty is highly unrealistic unless the whole map of the Middle East is thrown out the window.

*the above refers to the foreseeable future, i.e., the next 100 years.

With regard to Dermer, the Israeli ambassador to the United States, who said in a phone interview. “Their strategy is not to negotiate an agreement with Israel because a deal is give and take. They want take and take.”

Dermer sets the new standard for "white is black" bald-faced cray-cray. It is the Israelis who are "take and take." The arabs haven't proposed taking an inch of land west of the UN partition line.
No, they have only vowed, loud and proud,  to push the Jews into the sea!
Nice try, the war was started when Egypt shut down the Straits of Tiran to Israel and cleared all the UN soldiers out. It's called a declaration of war...read all about it...

Even decades ago, looking at the settlement map in the West Bank made it seem obvious that the plan is a Greater Israel, with the Jordan river as a well-defendable border. All talk and eternal "negotiations" about a two-state solution are not in good faith. Maybe it is time to spell it out. If Israel wants to remain a "Jewish Democracy", it has to pay whatever it costs to get the "Palestinians" settled somewhere else.

Arabs who heeded the call and fled Israel in 1948 are now enjoying their life in squalor of UN run refugee camps even after 65 years. The original partition called for a two state solutions, with the Arabs gaining the greater portion. They rejected it in favor of conflict and hopes of committing genocide against the Jews. The Israeli returned Gaza unilaterally, including the amazing modern greenhouse infrastructure abandoned by Israel. And what happened? The Arabs promptly destroyed the homes, synagogues and modern greenhouses and built missile launching sites to hit populated Israeli towns.
Why shouldn't the newcomers be the ones to go somewhere else, or back to where they came from?
And of course we will.
Yep.  Time to stop giving Israel $3.1 billion/year, as we did last year.   We could stop giving Egypt $1.5 billion/year, too.

Weellll... I can think of the aftermath of world wars where the victor (the US being one) rebuilt the war-torn cities and economies of their former enemies. Maybe you're too young or unschooled to know about the Marshall Plan?

Yup. They would still have Israel, all of it, which has never been threatened.They would have every inch described by the boundaries Israel voluntarily designated on declaring independence as per UN Res, 191 Part 2. Israelis have a country. They should learn to live in it.
Poor you. Did you miss that Jordan ceded territorial claims in 1988 -- to the Palestinians? Who's suggesting a revision of history?

Just a suggestion for people who hate exercise. DON'T walk on school tracks or use a treadmill. You will not enjoy it. Start out by taking a STROLL in the park or in the woods or along a beach. In a word enjoy nature. While strolling watch the trees and the animals. Stop occasionally to observe something interesting.
Repeat it in a different landscape. You might find out that your outings will become longer, that your stroll turns into a brisk walk eventually. And if not, stick with the stroll! Dont't be a hamster in his wheel, life is too short for martyrdom.

How many parents use the myth of being big-boned to make their overweight kids feel better about themselves, and then make sure they clean their plates at the three meals a day they feed them?

The biggest myth is that we need to eat three meals a day, and the worst meal of all to eat for the overweight is breakfast.

In other societies of yore, breakfast was not eaten- certainly it wasn't considered essential. Cicero wrote on the life of the average Roman schoolboy and breakfast was not eaten. At noon, a snack was ingested, with the big meal being in the late afternoon.

Do we REALLY need school lunch programs?

Kathryn- try skipping breakfast as a matter of routine with your first meal of the day at noon. Let the body's GI system rest for the first six hours of the day.

You might find that you feel better physically and mentally, and start to lose weight again.

But do it every day. That's the tough part for the first few weeks. Then you like it.
Those conditions are vanishingly rare. People are morbidly obese because they have developed maladaptive eating patterns. Genes play no role in it, either.

Amber, I agree with a lot of what you said. However, while healthy eating can surely lead to the cessation of many meds, there are many drugs necessary for sustaining one's life for many reasons. You can't say there are no meds for serious conditions/diseases can't sustain human life. They are very necessary for many in order to do just that.

I've witnessed more than a few patients, including an otherwise very healthy, beautiful and vibrant young woman suffer the degradation of Parkinson's. Without the meds, she would have suffered and died a whole lot sooner than she did, which was entirely too soon as it was. They buy all of them more time, as well as being able to sustain some dignity along the way.

I believe that any candidate for bariatric surgery should be thoroughly evaluated by an endocrinologist, which I do not believe is the current practice.  There are a number of endocrine disorders which can cause significant weight gain, and are treatable.  To go through this major surgery when another treatment would be more appropriate is a very disturbing prospect.

I have worked at 3 hospitals which specialize in bariatric surgery.
I've noticed that prospective patients undergo deep screening to make sure that their psychological and self image issues are realistic as to the "effect" that a surgical method of weight-loss will entail. In some ways these patients are examined almost as intensely as a patient trying to get on a kidney transplant list.

With the interest in a lucrative reimbursement in bariatric surgery, I think that some "practitioners" have minimized or skipped those aspects of the surgery that is dependent on the psychological needs and expectations of the patient. Bariatric surgery was once seen as the "last best chance" for someone whose morbid obesity threatened their life to the same degree as cancer,stroke,liver cirrhosis and renal failure.

The reimbursement for bariatric surgery has allowed some practitioners to focus on the benefit to their financial situation,as opposed to the evaluation of the impact and "success" on the patient.

This state of affairs is a uniquely American problem.Countries with rational health care systems, rarely see physicians with a "what is it worth to me,rather than what is the best outcome for my patient". If you cut enough corners in patient screening you can boost the first outcome (personal,financial),at the expense of the second (patient).

Wonderful article about bariatric surgery...but it didn't answer the big question it exposed at the end of the article. Why are those so unhappy after transforming their life for the better? Why are 100 million obese Americans so apprehensive about bariatric surgery that only 1 in 80 of eligible patients have gotten it?

As the article points out, the surgery drastically and permanently changes the hunger hormones that drive obesity. The problem is many of these same factors contribute to happiness.

Drug makers for years have been trying to make psychiatric medication that causes a positive effect but doesn't cause obesity. Its proven to be very elusive. And, blocking pleasurable hormones associated with obesity such as cannabis, the active ingredient in Marijuana, makes things worse. The blocking cannabis caused weight loss; however, it also caused severe anxiety, depression, and a doubling of the rate of suicide.

Bariatric surgery also changes the hormones that have a profound effects on emotions. So much, that 80-85% of patients divorce within two years after surgery, alcoholism & substance abuse all of a sudden develops or worsens after surgery, depression and anxiety spiral out of control, suicide rates dramatically increase, especially in men (800%).

The big questions aren't answered yet. Is Jessica's life better now that she dropped out of college? She sounds anxious & depressed? How will her bariatric physician help her? What happens next?

and Elke

L.J.K.- I am PLOTZing !

Dear Colonel: please see An adjacentarticle Re: about 16 to 19 K for the simple operation the sleeve I think, and 18 to 25K for the more complex Roux -en Y one. I'm in the middle of the article right now and it's a very lengthy one . Look for "after weight loss....disappointment…" It's about 15 digital pages long

Ask your doctor if you should fast for the first part of the day in order to get used to an empty stomach. And you might mention that you read somewhere that obesity is the result of maladaptive learned behavior.

If the doctor says either 1) that you can't skip breakfast because it is the most important meal of the day, or 2) you must eat breakfast in order to get the metabolic machinery going, or 3) you need something in your stomach to support your morning glucose levels, or 4) you need to eat in the morning to keep from REALLY getting hungry in the afternoon and REALLY overeating......well, get another doctor.
People can't control their color, of course, but they can control their weight.
